document_data.name: Dung
document_data.mainbody:
'''Dung''' was a waste product commonly used as fuel for cooking and heating in the [[Forgotten Realms|Realms]]. The word in [[Common]] was '''''naeth'''''.

Heaps of dung were sometimes found within dungeons, and bat dung, known as '''guano''', was actively mined in many lands in [[Faerûn]].
document_data.Properties: [[Alchemist]]s claimed that the dung of certain [[dragon]]s had many special properties, such as quick ignition even in cold or wet conditions and the production of an intense blue flame. A [[red dragon]]'s dung contained significant quantities of [[potassium nitrate]] and [[sulfur]], making it potentially explosive, as well as metal and stone [[Wikipedia:gastrolith|stomach stones]].<ref>{{Cite dragon/134/The Ecology of the Red Dragon|36}}
document_data.Reputation: Words for dung in various languages were used as curses. ''Naeth'' was considered mild, but when pronounced '''''naed''''', the word was considered stronger language.
document_data.Variations:
The dung produced by [[cow]]s was referred to as cow chips by inhabitants of [[Waterdeep]] and the [[Delimbiyr Vale]]. The cow dung scent was similar to the smell of [[Modovian dung beetle]]s.

[[Mephit]] guano was a substance with some magical properties. It was used to [[enchant]] items and, if thrown, exploded in a deadly ''[[stinking cloud]]''. Carrying such items around was frowned upon and their stench was surely to scare people away.
document_data.Trivia:
* One of the entrances to the city of [[Zazesspur]] was called the [[Dung Gate]].
* Personal [[hygiene]] in regards of cleaning nightsoil off varied. Some used hand-scoop method, travelers could use sand along a river bank, others "skidded their bum along in the snow," the wealthy were known to use scented [[thareea]] wipe cloths, as well as tough leaves of the [[thallow]] and [[yahllavur-fern]] plants.{{cite web| url = https://web.archive.org/web/20240405041010/http://www.candlekeep.com/library/articles/sse/sse_010203-06.htm| title = So Saith Ed Jan – Mar 2006| accessdate = 5-4-2024| date = 23-1-2006}}
